caption:
This photograph appears to depict a microscopic view of crystalline structures, possibly ice or some mineral. The frame is predominantly filled with various elongated, needle-like crystals that are sharp and radiate from certain focal points, suggesting this could be a magnified image of a freezing process or crystallization.

The background is a deep, dark blue, effectively highlighting the intricate details of the crystalline structures which are illuminated and appear luminescent. Most of the crystals are thin and elongated, while others seem to aggregate around thicker central spines. The image also includes several smaller, out-of-focus white and blue dots scattered across the entirety of the frame, enhancing the depth and complexity of the visual.

Towards the upper left, thereâ€™s a spherical formation that stands out due to its solid, grainy texture and stark contrast to the slender, sharp crystals around it. This sphere looks like it could be a tiny, possibly frozen particle or a mineral aggregate.

Overall, the image provides a fascinating visual study of crystal growth under magnification, providing an almost alien, otherworldly look at common natural processes, likely captured with some form of specialized imaging like microscopy or macro photography.
title: Close- up of ice fractures and air bubbles in an iced over lake.  Photo taken at tin lake mine, Washington, near Seattle, Washington.  From the environmental protection agencys project documerica collection, "in praise of forests".  For more images see fiche #s 209, 210, 211, 212, and 213.  Entheos.  January, 1974.
